segments.text: Okay, maybe a bit on the second question you ask about what's one of the new offshore claims doing to research.

Well, first of all, it's especially delicate in the United States because we find oil on some of our own coastlines, and the U.S. Geological Survey is now starting to work heavily on our own coastlines.
And so you don't find as much opportunity to work there on our own coast as we did before.
And the foreign coasts are more and more closed to us.
So this is, in some sense, pushing us into deep water.
But it needn't be all bleak.
We can get some work done with the geological survey, and we can get some work done with other countries.
I think it just means we have to have more cooperative programs, is what it turns out.
And we have to cultivate our contacts very carefully, especially in other countries, if we want to work off their coast.
And we sure include them in plans.
But that's a natural evolution of things in many respects.
For a while, the United States had a very strong and unique position in oceanography.
And now these other countries are developing their own capabilities, and they would like to be included in plans.
It's quite understandable.
So I don't look upon it as quite such a bleak thing as some people do.
I think people can do research together.
It's almost a tradition in National Archive anyway to work with people in other countries.
I don't see that being any catastrophe that's going to rush on us.
So I don't really worry too much about that, I guess.
We're continually traveling and continually meeting people and working with them.
And we have very little political problems with our own scientific level.
The people that we worry about most are some of the developing countries who don't understand what we're doing and are naturally very suspicious.
And we feel that that's unfortunate, that they wouldn't be suspicious if they knew us.
But that will be able to come in time, I suppose.
Well, I'm sure they confuse oceanographic vessels with the regular sort of spy vessel that comes close to their shore.
Well, they do that.

But there's another concern that they have that is quite understandable, that even if you're not a spy vessel, if you're just a scientific vessel and not one of their own, some other country will have the scientific data.
Mm-hmm.
And whether those scientists are mean to or not, very likely that data will be spread out to people of their own country for commercial exploitation quicker than it would be for their own people.

So these kinds of concerns, just the very fact that you're gathering the data and not that you're really trying to have any clearly subversive means, that in itself appears to be a threat to some of the countries in that.
So it's a very delicate thing about how you work off the shores.
We have had some problems in some countries, but we're not panicking yet.
Excuse me.
Your relationship with other scientists.
Which countries seem to produce the best oceanographers?
Oceanography now, you know, is many things to many people.
And as far as marine geophysics goes, Britain has had a very good reputation.
And the United States has done fairly well.
Canada now is doing quite well, and Japan is coming along very well.
Those countries are coming along probably faster than the Soviet Union.
Some countries are just getting into it, but getting into it fast.
Germany, West Germany, and France.
For many years, France had almost no marine physics program.
And over the last few years, they've tried very hard to improve that situation.
But you know, regardless of how you interpret the word oceanography, some countries have no oceanographic capability at all.
Many in South America are trying very hard to develop oceanographic sentence.
But it's a very difficult thing when they've got severe internal problems.
It seems quite a luxury to them to go off and be studying things under the water, unless it's biological.
The biological side is a very practical benefit from the fisheries work.
So they frequently can see that as a first effort in marine science.

We've had contact, as I think many institutions in the United States have, with a lot of the Latin American and South American countries, and this is very important to them, as well as other places in the Middle East and here and there.
Fisheries is a big thing.
But we've had contact with almost every country of any size in the world, and it's kind of pleasant working with them.
When did you make your first voyage?
Oh, my.
First voyage, that was...
The first voyage of any consequence for scientific research was made in about 1960, I guess, on the Vima.
It was Vima cruise number 17, I think it was, off of the west coast of South America.
Because I had been in the Navy before that, so I had... Yeah, been to sea before.
It's a little frightening to think back when you first went to sea and realize it's been over 30 years since you've been to sea.
But I think there have been something like a dozen and a half cruises I've been on, more or less, one kind or another.
And almost every part of the world, except the...
high northern southern latitudes.
I've had research programs there, but I haven't been on cruises there.
I've had research programs in the Arctic on the ice islands.
I've had Antarctic on the ice of Antarctica.
I've been to every part of the world, so it's been quite interesting.
Do you think oceanographers should go to sea?
Yes, I do.
I feel rather strongly about that.
Maybe if you're a physical oceanographer and a theoretical type person, where you are just doing mathematical calculations, then maybe it's not so important.
But if you're dealing with data acquired at sea, I think it's really very important that you get to sea so that you understand how that data is acquired.
Especially in marine geophysics and marine geology, I think you really
add a great deal of perspective by going to sea.
It's one of the few professions that you can get in and you do everything from manhandling gear and working with your muscles to working with your brain.
And you have to do a whole range of things and that makes for kind of an interesting job, I think.
Many people like that challenge.
You have to battle yourself against the elements when you go to sea.
And there's a lot of
People have an interest in doing that now.
I think there are many stories about young people who found themselves at sea.
They didn't quite know what to do on land, but when they get to sea and have to face a real challenge, a physical challenge, then they find something very satisfying in that.
So you find a very interesting bunch of people, I think, in oceanography.
It only seemed that way to me.
Well, there's been some complaint, as a matter of fact, that younger oceanographers don't go to sea often enough.
That's right.
Don't get their feet wet is the word, I think, that one of your older colleagues used.
Yeah, that's right.
I would agree with that.
It's really rather important.

As a matter of fact, for students who are planning to study oceanography, I think it's very important that they go to sea before they decide to take up oceanography as a profession, to see if they like the ocean, because...
There's a general tendency either to like it very much or dislike it very much.
And lots of people just hate the water.
They just think it's a physically disturbing environment to be in, and it's a risky environment, and it's disturbing to family life, et cetera, et cetera.
And you just shouldn't be there.
Others look upon it as a real challenge, and it's meant for only a few people.
They're proud to be one of those few.
So we try to encourage students to go on a cruise
We don't know what they're getting in for.
But I'm sure that's going to change in the future.
I'm sure we're going to have lots of oceanographers that don't go out and face the elements like these.
Well, now, you anticipate the next question.
With the advent of such things as modeling becoming more and more important in oceanography, it looks to me like a number of those people will drop.
And consequently, many older oceanographers are
chronologically older oceanographers.
I mean, I don't mean so much in age, but those who came through the older institutions or opposed to... Well, basically what's happening is people are specializing, you see.
And their little piece of the action doesn't necessarily mean that they go to sea.
They can design an instrument, for example, and have somebody else test it in sea.
Or even if they go to sea, they don't have to repair all the instruments.
You have electronic specialists for this and for that and for that, and you have computer specialists now who go to sea.
At this institution, they go to sea quite regularly.
We have computers go to sea all the time, general-purpose computers that do general-purpose plotting and amalgamating data and massaging data and whatnot and whatnot.
And it used to be that one individual had to do all those things, besides tell the captain of the ship which way to go and look out for the weather and dodge the hurricanes and so on and so on.
You don't have to do that very much anymore.
It's the other people who do that.
Navigation is getting much easier.
Some of the electronics is getting quite sophisticated, too, so it's just not possible for a person to know the whole range of things.
Now, it requires some pretty good electronics engineers to handle some of the equipment we have.
We have real-time, multi-channel seismic processing going on on ships at sea, for example.
It requires fairly good knowledge of computer processing and other instruments.
And we have them all recorded digitally now.
It's all digital recording.
on mag tape, and that's happened in the last ten years or so, or less even, I guess.
Before it was all recording it by simple machine and pins and whatnot.
It's all changed now.
But I don't think the field of oceanography is going to collapse, nor will it grow very fast.
I think it will probably have a slow and orderly growth.
I think the interest in it has grown faster than the field itself could be expected to grow.
And to that extent, I blame the educational institutions in not having a better feel for how many new people the business needs.
This happens all across our society, but we ought to have, with this day and time, we should have a better
understanding of how many people we should train.
Okay, well, let me pose this question for you, then.

It's almost as if, from an outsider, uh, point of view, it's almost as if the NSF, uh, well, that'd be too strong, but at least those people associated with O&R who move into various National Science Foundation projects, in, let's say, the mid-50s, it's almost as if they went out to establish, uh,
departments and academic institutions scattered across the country, to name a few for you.
Fleming goes to Washington, for example, to establish one.
Burt goes down to Oregon State not too many years later.
There's one established at Texas A&M for Gulf Coast oceanography.
There's one established in Miami when Walton Smith goes down to Miami.
And I'm sure I could list others if I could think about it, but those come to mind.
Each one of those seem to be as if it's almost deliberate.
Do you think that, through hindsight, that was a mistake on the part of grant-giving institutions?
That was clearly a response to political pressure that that happened.
And there's nothing wrong in that.
I think if you...
If you jeopardize national goals by spreading your meager resources out too thin, then it's unforgivable.
But sure, I think all these places ought to have the opportunity to learn something about oceanography.
But we have to be careful about, number one, the funds that are available, and number two, how many students we turn out.
We can't just expect the Congress of the United States to appropriate funds
at the whim of the American young people who choose to find it very interesting this year to go into, because of the film Jaws or something, they decide to go into oceanography.

And it's not logical, I think, that the American taxpayer is supposed to support that kind of interest which may be passing, especially if these people, once they've graduated, expect to work in oceanography, and there are no jobs.
So it's interesting.
If it's done as an entertainment, that's one thing.
But I don't know.
I think there are a number of us that got into the business simply because we couldn't hardly have done anything else.
I mean, we just were kind of addicted by it.
If they cut our pay in half, that wouldn't make any difference about whether we were at work or not.
We were still at work.
But there are a few people, I think, who have a certain degree of dedication, and others that approach it as a curiosity or as an amusement.
And I don't think you should expect American taxpayer to support all these people.
So I think physics is the same way right now.
There hasn't been a good understanding between the educational institutions that haven't really understood how many people they should produce.
They've never put, of course, any limit on how many people in a profession want to get trained in one profession.
But I really think that they do have some obligation
point out to students that if you enter as a freshman this year and intend to go through this particular course, that you will very likely have an extremely hard time when you get out.
And that would tend, I think, to shut the students down paths that would be more helpful to them and to society.
And you don't see much of that anymore, I guess.
And that happens.
I know there's some schools, so I won't mention any names, that turn out just any number of
people in oceanography, and many of them have no jobs that they can go to, or no job that they're really proud of.
Well, I think that's a mistake.
I think it's careless.
That's like having children without thinking what you're doing.
It's having graduates without thinking what you're doing.
It's just as careless.
So that happens a lot in the United States, I'm afraid.
Not only in the United States.
Right now it's happening in Britain, I think.
Marine research opportunities are extremely limited in Britain right now, and funds are very short, but yet they're turning out a large number of students.
Good students, much, but they have to leave Britain.
They just can't work in Britain.
We see a lot coming to this country.
We see a lot coming to Canada.
Well, countries this day and time ought to be able to control that situation better and still keep people happy in their professions.
Because right now, we're keeping them unhappy, I think, in that profession, these young people.
So anyway, that's it.
OK. Now, I want to, if I may, drop backwards in the interview again, OK?
Sure.
I wanted to pursue those questions while they were available.
At Lamont, OK, what do you do when you leave Lamont?
What does who do?
You do.
What did I do?
Where did you go?
I was director of a laboratory called the Hudson Laboratories.
at Columbia University.
It was in Dobbs Fair, New York, across the river from Lamont.
It makes kind of an interesting story, I think.
I'm not sure, going to all the details here, but that was a laboratory that was established after the Second World War to do acoustics research for the Navy.
The Navy had no academic laboratory like that, at least not on the East Coast at that time.
And they wanted an academic laboratory, and so they established this through the physics department at Columbia.
And through the years, they had become terribly caught up in classified research.
They had become more and more of a classified laboratory.
And they decided in 1967, I'm shortening this quite a bit, to make it a laboratory that was
not doing so much classified research, so it could be integrated into the university.
And they asked me if I'd come over and help them do that.
There was new facilities and so forth.
Well, this was just at the time of student unrest in Columbia.
And Columbia was one of the first schools that really blew up in those days.
And the students were not about to wait for any kind of orderly change.
They went into the president's office and pulled out the classified documents and threw them out in the yard and so forth and so on.
And frankly, the Navy got very upset at this and told the senior administration there that, in effect, that they couldn't tolerate a situation like this.
Either they would have to get the laboratory under control quite quickly and integrate it into the university, or they couldn't continue the laboratory.
The administration in those days at Columbia couldn't handle the situation for a number of reasons, mainly the student problems.
The student pressure was much too great, and it was almost dangerous to raise your voice against a student in those days.
But the Navy decided to close the lab, and they decided, after I'd been there a relatively few months, to close that lab.
and not wait for a change.
My point of view is that the Navy should have given us more time.
And the Navy felt otherwise, and they closed it.
And the lab was closed in 1969, spring of 1969.
They had large ships, and we were going at what I would consider an amazing speed of diversifying the lab and reducing the classification problem.
But nevertheless, the Navy didn't see
fit to continue that.
Well, shortly after that, the president and other administrative officials resigned from Columbia University, but nevertheless, it's unfortunate, the lab got caught in the squeeze.
The students, of course, had no idea of what damage they had done, that they put four hundred people out of work and so forth and so on, and
tremendous personal ramifications throughout the whole lab, that disruption.
But then sometimes students don't stop to think about those things.
But anyway, it was one of those situations where the university administration, the student, and the Defense Department pressures all came to bear on that lab.
So I stayed until the doors were closed, finally closed.
And then I came to Woods Hole after that.
And was your choice to come to Woods Hole primarily based on the closing of that lab?
Yes.
It was.
Yes.
I felt it would do me good to get away from Columbia at that time.
Well, that really was what I was implying.
It had nothing to do with... No, no.
I was offered a very nice position back in Lamont, and I thought it was best that I not stay with them at that time.
After all, well, for a number of reasons, I just felt it was probably best that I get away from that particular situation.
Since then, it's all quieted down, of course.
Yeah, there are no more students who are doing these kinds of things.
Right.
And Woods Hole is a lovely place to be.
It's really quite nice.
It's grown tremendously since I've been here.
Right.
Now, so when you decided to come here in 69, what sort of position did you come in as a senior researcher?
Yes, I was chairman of the Department of Geology and Physics.
And I continued that position until last year.
when I resigned, just because I knew there were other good people who could do the job quite adequately.
And it was good for some kind of a change.
And we did.
We were very fortunate we got John Ewing here.
But I came as chairman of the Department of Geophysics.
And I think I might have made a few improvements around here.
Well, now you've also anticipated the next question.
Did you have something in mind you wanted to do with the department when you came?
Yes, I did.
The effort at Woods Hole was fragmented.
They had a number of very good people here, but they were all kind of going in different directions.
And as a matter of fact, this had been known as a place, and still is in many ways, known as a place where you have a lot of independent research groups.
And trying to get those people to aim all their forces in one direction was quite a challenge.

without trying to destroy anyone's personal interest or distort their approach to science, you can find common threads that go through groups like this and make kind of more of a spirit de corps in the department.
And I think that's happened.
We've improved the result tremendously.
I think it was fine-tuning, is what you would call it.
We put the right groups next to the right groups.
We've got different types of ships now than we had when I came.
This whole campus where we sit now, 200 acres, we didn't have that in those days.
All of the building program here has come since that time.
The educational program was just getting started then.
Now we have quite a respectable educational program, plus other programs.
So it's been a good period of development here.
In the last seven years?
Yeah.
We had a budget, I don't know, it must have been about
five or six million dollars a year, maybe eight when I came, and now we're at twenty-two million.
So it's grown.
It's a big institution now.
And helping it grow has been kind of fun.
And there have been some growing pains, but it happens in every organization.
When you first go to see, many years ago, and
Given the way vessels operate now, what do you think are the major technological changes on the vessels which make oceanographic vessels more efficient?
Well, everybody has profited greatly by the navigational procedures.
You know, they were really extremely crude thirty years ago.
Getting a ship across the ocean was just unbelievably crude.
You were never quite sure when you were going to make a landfall where you were.
But today, you have such precise navigation equipment.
You can go out and you can sail for three weeks outside of land, and yet you go out and find a bump that's not much bigger than an automobile on the seafloor, things of that kind.
You can do that now.
And you couldn't do that before.
So one of the major things has been the use of satellites.
Satellite navigation has just made a quantum jump in our navigational accuracy.
But there have been other things.
a whole new electronic technology, the micro-miniaturization of circuits.
It's just been a great boom.
And the knowledge is improved in all fields.
We're working from an entirely different database than we did in those days.
In those days, everything was new.
Everything you did was new.
Now it's not so.
Almost everywhere, you could dive in your submersible out in the Midlantic Ridge and
travel a mile or two, you'll find a track where somebody's dragged something across the sea floor, thrown a Coke bottle.
So it's not the wild forest that it was when it used to be.
Now we're understanding it.
But that's familiarity.
That's not technology, really.
I think computer technology, the micrometeorization of electronics, and the satellite navigation, I can't
overstate the importance of satellite navigation.
That's just been superb.
For a reasonable price, you can locate yourself within a couple hundred feet in the middle of the ocean, which is quite something.
That's the essential thing.
The ships haven't improved much.
I must say that was something I would have expected that would have improved more.
But they're still the same, basically the same old things, and you still move at a speed
snail's pace across the ocean.
We were predicting in those days that you'd have ships that wouldfast boats that would shuttle scientists out to platforms back and forth.
That hasn't happened.
We still have the same old chug, chug, chug, chug, chug that gets us across the ocean.
Hardly more reliable than they were in those days.
Creature comforts are a little better, not much.
As a matter of fact, I guess losing sails, taking sails off ship was a thing that many people regret.
So pleasant.
Communications, of course, has greatly improved, too.

The fact that you can talk freely to your ships and your colleagues who are at sea in any part of the world just by picking up the telephone right here and calling a radio show and getting them on the phone.
And you do it quite casually.
You ask them, what's happening today?
What about that experiment you were planning yesterday?
How did it come off today?
You can do that.
What did you have for breakfast and so forth?
That would be a change indeed.
Yes, it is.
Now, in terms of discoveries which were made during your career, oceanographic discoveries or others, what amazed you the most?
What took you the most aback, you the least expected?
Well, the simplicity of sea flow spreading is far and away the most mind-boggling thing.
I think it's hard for a person who's not in the field to understand why you should get so shook up about that.
I don't know whether you want to deviate to the personal side.
Maybe you do.
Maybe that's one of the advantages of a thing like this.
But I can remember very clearly several instances that stood out in my mind that made quite an impression on me.
And I've told these on one or two other occasions.
I can't remember whether they were recent or not.
But in the theory of seafloor spreading, two things were happening in those days when we were studying seafloor spreading.
One is we were studying about the motions of the continents across the seafloor.
And not in an idle capacity, but in a very precise, we could give the year and the position of where it was.
And secondarily, we were learning something about the Earth's magnetic field, that it reversed, and when it reversed, and how it reversed.
And these two rather abstract things, I never thought when I was small that I'd ever get shook up about some sort of a silly thing like that.
But there was one night in particular when
I had been working on the reconstructing the Earth's magnetic field history of how it reversed.

And I knew, I was quite certain one night when I went to bed at 4 o'clock in the morning, having worked on several computers for a long time, because we had trial and error methods and we had to use a lot of computer time to run these things through.
I knew that I was the only person in the world that knew what had happened to the Earth's magnetic field for a period of 10 million years.

Now, I've always claimed that geologists who talk about a million years here, or 500 million years, or 10 million years, don't really stop and try to appreciate what quantity of time they're talking about.
But we were dealing in very precise quantities, and we knew just exactly what was happening on the Earth at some point 7.256 million years ago.
And whatever creatures lived on the Earth, we weren't biologists very much.
We didn't know much of this time.
We knew the general types of animals.
But those creatures were living in it.
We knew an awful lot about a small segment of their environment.
And we were absolutely sure we were right.
